Pros: He's will help if you attend sessions and offers retakes (though much harder).

Cons: Harsh grader — deducts points for every minute detail and it feels like he's almost working against you. Extremely time-consuming class with homework taking 2-3 hours per assignment, and 3 assignments per week. Made this class harder than diff eq and linear.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lots of homework--Accessible outside class

comment: Professor Cueva is not a bad teacher but he's an impossible grader who works against you. You're not allowed to memorize anything for tests which becomes really taxing later in the course. He'll give some partial credit, but VERY little of it. You have 30-50 HW questions a week. He also frequently belittles students for questions.

DO take this class if:

You are a math heavy major and need to MASTER Algebra

You can learn easily by yourself with minimal instruction

You know your multiplication table, perfect squares, square roots, forwards, backwards, left and right

You know how to ask questions using proper mathematic terms

PS: Quiz every Friday. I failed each one.

He explains the why rather than the how for each concept. The lack of review is annoying and his lectures don't translate well to the students. If you don't do it exactly to his liking, you miss the whole problem. NO PARTIAL CREDIT! Allows some retakes for points. Take another calc professor; the final exam contained concepts not even taught before

I love Professor Cueva. He is a tough grader, but makes up for it in extra credit opportunities. He also gives you the whole semester to improve quiz grades. Most homework assignments are long, but prepare you well for the tests/quizzes. And he always does recaps of what you should have learned in previous courses before he introduces new topics.

Professor Cueva is a very harsh grader on tests that hardly relate to the resources we have to study. He also does not care about his students almost as if he wants us to fail his class. He seems passionate about what he teaches, but this does not translate well to his students.
